docs.title: 🐍 Python Cheatsheet
docs.text: Welcome to your Python cheatsheet! A lightning-fast reference for everyday Python programming.

docs.title: 🔧 Sections
docs.text:
• Basics — variables, types, loops
  • Data Structures — lists, tuples, sets, dicts
  • Functions — definitions, args, lambdas
  • OOP — classes, inheritance, dunder methods
  • File Handling — reading, writing, JSON
  • Shortcuts — one-liners, tips, tricks

docs.title: 🐍 Python Basics Cheatsheet
docs.text: A concise reference for Python fundamentals — variables, data types, operators, and control flow.

docs.title: ⚙️ 1. Python Syntax Overview
docs.text:
# This is a comment
print("Hello, World!")  # Output: Hello, World!

docs.title: Indentation
docs.text:
Python uses indentation to define blocks (no {} needed).

if True:
    print("Indented block")

docs.title: 💡 2. Variables
docs.text:
No need to declare types — Python is dynamically typed.

x = 10
name = "Alice"
pi = 3.14
is_active = True

Reassigning changes type dynamically:

x = "Now I'm a string!"

docs.title: 🧮 3. Data Types
docs.text: Type Example Description int 42 Whole numbers float 3.1415 Decimal numbers str "Hello" Text bool True, False Logical values list [1, 2, 3] Ordered, mutable collection tuple (1, 2, 3) Ordered, immutable collection set {1, 2, 3} Unordered, unique values dict {"a": 1, "b": 2} Key-value pairs

docs.title: ✍️ 4. Strings
docs.text:
name = "Python"
print(name.lower())
print(name.upper())
print(name[0:3])  # Slicing
print(len(name))

docs.title: String Formatting
docs.text:
age = 25
print(f"My age is {age}")  # f-string
print("My age is {}".format(age))

docs.title: ➕ 5. Operators
docs.text: Type Operators Example Result Arithmetic +, -, *, /, //, %, ** 5 ** 2 25 Comparison ==, !=, >, <, >=, <= 5 > 3 True Logical and, or, not x > 0 and y < 10 — Assignment =, +=, -=, *= x += 5 — Membership in, not in 'a' in 'cat' True Identity is, is not x is y —

docs.title: 🔁 6. Conditionals
docs.text:
age = 18

if age >= 18:
    print("Adult")
elif age > 13:
    print("Teenager")
else:
    print("Child")

Ternary Expression:

status = "Adult" if age >= 18 else "Minor"

docs.title: For Loop
docs.text:
for i in range(5):
    print(i)

docs.title: While Loop
docs.text:
count = 0
while count < 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

docs.title: Loop Control Statements
docs.text:
for n in range(10):
    if n == 3:
        continue  # Skip 3
    if n == 8:
        break     # Stop at 8
    print(n)

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
fruits.append("orange")
print(fruits[0])  # Access first item

docs.title: Tuples
docs.text:
point = (3, 4)
print(point[0])

docs.title: Sets
docs.text:
nums = {1, 2, 3, 3}
print(nums)  # {1, 2, 3}

docs.title: Dictionaries
docs.text:
person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
print(person["name"])
person["age"] = 26

docs.title: 🧮 9. List Comprehensions
docs.text:
A concise way to create lists.

squares = [x**2 for x in range(5)]
evens = [n for n in range(10) if n % 2 == 0]

docs.title: ⚠️ 10. Exception Handling
docs.text:
try:
    num = int(input("Enter a number: "))
except ValueError:
    print("That's not a number!")
else:
    print("You entered:", num)
finally:
    print("Done!")

docs.title: 🧰 11. Type Conversion
docs.text:
x = 10
print(str(x))  # "10"
print(float(x))  # 10.0
print(int("20"))  # 20

docs.title: 🕒 12. Useful Built-ins
docs.text:
abs(-5)      # 5
round(3.7)   # 4
len("hello") # 5
sum([1,2,3]) # 6
sorted([3,1,2]) # [1,2,3]

docs.title: 🧠 13. Input & Output
docs.text:
name = input("Enter your name: ")
print("Hello,", name)

docs.title: ✅ 14. Best Practices
docs.text:
✅ Use clear, descriptive variable names ✅ Follow PEP 8 style guide ✅ Keep indentation consistent (4 spaces) ✅ Use with for file handling ✅ Comment wisely and write readable code

🔗 Related Topics: - Functions - File Handling - Data Structures

© Python Cheatsheet — Basics Section

docs.title: 🧱 Python Data Structures Cheatsheet
docs.text: Master Python’s core data structures — lists, tuples, sets, and dictionaries — with practical examples.

docs.title: 📋 1. Lists
docs.text:
Mutable, ordered collections of items.

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

docs.title: Common Operations
docs.text:
fruits.append("orange")     # Add
fruits.remove("banana")     # Remove
fruits.insert(1, "kiwi")    # Insert at index
fruits.pop()                # Remove last item
fruits.sort()               # Sort list
fruits.reverse()            # Reverse order
print(len(fruits))          # Length

docs.title: List Slicing
docs.text:
numbers = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
print(numbers[1:4])   # [1, 2, 3]
print(numbers[::-1])  # Reverse

docs.title: List Comprehension
docs.text:
squares = [x**2 for x in range(5)]
even = [n for n in range(10) if n % 2 == 0]

docs.title: 🪄 2. Tuples
docs.text:
Immutable and ordered collections — great for fixed data.

point = (3, 4)
print(point[0])  # 3

docs.title: Tuple Unpacking
docs.text:
x, y = point
print(x, y)

docs.title: One-Element Tuple
docs.text:
single = (5,)
print(type(single))  # <class 'tuple'>

⚠️ Without the comma → (5) is just an int.

docs.title: 🧩 3. Sets
docs.text:
Unordered, mutable collections of unique items.

nums = {1, 2, 3, 3, 2}
print(nums)  # {1, 2, 3}

docs.title: Set Operations
docs.text:
a = {1, 2, 3}
b = {3, 4, 5}

print(a | b)  # Union → {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}
print(a & b)  # Intersection → {3}
print(a - b)  # Difference → {1, 2}
print(a ^ b)  # Symmetric difference → {1, 2, 4, 5}

docs.title: Useful Methods
docs.text:
s = {10, 20, 30}
s.add(40)
s.remove(20)
s.discard(50)  # Safe remove (no error)

docs.title: 🧰 4. Dictionaries
docs.text:
Key-value pairs, mutable and unordered (since Python 3.7, they maintain insertion order).

person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}

docs.title: Access and Modify
docs.text:
print(person["name"])
person["age"] = 26
person["city"] = "New York"

docs.title: Dictionary Methods
docs.text:
print(person.keys())      # dict_keys(['name', 'age', 'city'])
print(person.values())    # dict_values(['Alice', 26, 'New York'])
print(person.items())     # dict_items([('name', 'Alice'), ('age', 26), ('city', 'New York')])

docs.title: Looping
docs.text:
for key, value in person.items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")

docs.title: Dictionary Comprehension
docs.text: squares = {x: x**2 for x in range(5)}

docs.title: 🧮 5. Nested Data Structures
docs.text:
You can combine structures:

users = [
    {"name": "Alice", "age": 25},
    {"name": "Bob", "age": 30},
]
print(users[0]["name"])  # Alice

docs.title: Stack (LIFO)
docs.text:
stack = [1, 2, 3]
stack.append(4)
stack.pop()  # Removes 4

docs.title: Queue (FIFO)
docs.text:
from collections import deque

queue = deque(["a", "b", "c"])
queue.append("d")
queue.popleft()  # Removes 'a'

docs.title: 🧮 7. Useful Built-ins
docs.text: Function Description Example len() Count items len([1,2,3]) → 3 sum() Add numbers sum([1,2,3]) → 6 sorted() Return a sorted copy sorted({3,1,2}) → [1,2,3] min() / max() Smallest / largest value min([3,5,1]) → 1 all() True if all items true all([1, True, 3]) → True any() True if any item true any([0, 0, 1]) → True

docs.title: ⚙️ 8. Copying Collections
docs.text:
import copy

a = [1, 2, [3, 4]]
b = a.copy()       # Shallow copy
c = copy.deepcopy(a)  # Deep copy

docs.title: ✅ 10. Best Practices
docs.text:
Use lists for ordered data Use tuples for fixed data Use sets to remove duplicates Use dictionaries for key-value mapping Use comprehensions for concise creation

🔗 Related Topics: - Basics - Functions - File Handling

© Python Cheatsheet — Data Structures Section

docs.title: 🗂️ Python File Handling Cheatsheet
docs.text: Master the essentials of working with files in Python — reading, writing, managing, and handling exceptions.

docs.title: 📖 1. Opening Files
docs.text:
Use the built-in open() function.

file = open("example.txt", "r")  # Modes: r, w, a, x, b, t
content = file.read()
file.close()

docs.title: Common Modes
docs.text: Mode Description r Read (default) w Write (overwrites file) a Append x Create (fails if file exists) b Binary mode t Text mode (default) r+ Read and write

docs.title: 🧠 2. Using with (Context Manager)
docs.text:
Automatically handles closing files — the best practice.

with open("data.txt", "r") as file:
    data = file.read()
print("File closed:", file.closed)

docs.title: ✍️ 3. Writing to Files
docs.text:
with open("notes.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("First line\n")
    f.write("Second line\n")

💡 Using w overwrites the file; use a to append.

docs.title: 📜 4. Reading Files
docs.text:
with open("notes.txt", "r") as f:
    print(f.read())        # Entire file
    f.seek(0)
    print(f.readline())    # One line
    f.seek(0)
    print(f.readlines())   # List of lines

docs.title: 🧩 5. Working with Binary Files
docs.text:
with open("image.png", "rb") as f:
    bytes_data = f.read()

To write binary data:

with open("copy.png", "wb") as f:
    f.write(bytes_data)

docs.title: 🔄 6. Checking File Existence
docs.text:
import os

if os.path.exists("notes.txt"):
    print("File exists")
else:
    print("File not found")

Or use pathlib (modern and preferred):

from pathlib import Path

path = Path("notes.txt")
if path.exists():
    print("File exists")

docs.title: 🗑️ 7. Deleting and Renaming Files
docs.text:
import os

os.rename("old_name.txt", "new_name.txt")
os.remove("unnecessary.txt")

Or with pathlib:

path = Path("old.txt")
path.rename("new.txt")
path.unlink()  # Deletes the file

docs.title: 📂 8. Directory Handling
docs.text:
os.mkdir("my_folder")
os.rmdir("my_folder")
os.listdir(".")  # List files in current directory

pathlib version:

p = Path("my_folder")
p.mkdir(exist_ok=True)
for file in p.iterdir():
    print(file)

docs.title: ⚠️ 9. Handling File Exceptions
docs.text:
try:
    with open("data.txt") as f:
        print(f.read())
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("File does not exist!")
except PermissionError:
    print("Permission denied!")

docs.title: CSV
docs.text:
import csv

# Writing
with open("data.csv", "w", newline="") as f:
    writer = csv.writer(f)
    writer.writerow(["Name", "Age"])
    writer.writerow(["Alice", 30])

# Reading
with open("data.csv", "r") as f:
    reader = csv.reader(f)
    for row in reader:
        print(row)

docs.title: JSON
docs.text:
import json

data = {"name": "Bob", "age": 25}

with open("data.json", "w") as f:
    json.dump(data, f)

with open("data.json", "r") as f:
    loaded = json.load(f)
    print(loaded)

docs.title: 🧼 11. Tips & Best Practices
docs.text:
Always use with open() for safety Use pathlib over os when possible Validate file paths before reading/writing Close files explicitly if not using with ßHandle exceptions for robust code

© Python Cheatsheet — File Handling Section

docs.title: ⚙️ Python Functions Cheatsheet
docs.text: A comprehensive guide to defining, calling, and mastering functions in Python.

docs.title: 🧩 1. Defining a Function
docs.text:
Use def followed by the function name and parentheses.

def greet():
    print("Hello, world!")

greet()

docs.title: Positional Parameters
docs.text:
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

print(add(3, 5))  # Output: 8

docs.title: Default Parameters
docs.text:
def power(base, exp=2):
    return base ** exp

print(power(4))    # 16
print(power(4, 3)) # 64

docs.title: Keyword Arguments
docs.text:
def describe_pet(animal, name):
    print(f"{name} is a {animal}.")

describe_pet(name="Buddy", animal="dog")

docs.title: Arbitrary Arguments
docs.text:
def add_all(*args):
    return sum(args)

print(add_all(1, 2, 3, 4))  # 10

docs.title: Arbitrary Keyword Arguments
docs.text:
def display_info(**kwargs):
    for key, value in kwargs.items():
        print(f"{key}: {value}")

display_info(name="Alice", age=30)

docs.title: 🪄 3. Return Values
docs.text:
def square(x):
    return x * x

result = square(5)
print(result)

Return multiple values:

def stats(a, b):
    return a + b, a * b

sum_, product = stats(3, 4)
print(sum_, product)

docs.title: 🧰 4. Docstrings
docs.text:
Document your function using triple quotes.

def greet(name):
    '''Return a greeting for the given name.'''
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

View docstring:

help(greet)
print(greet.__doc__)

docs.title: ⚙️ 5. Lambda (Anonymous) Functions
docs.text:
Small one-liners for simple operations.

square = lambda x: x ** 2
print(square(4))  # 16

Example with map() and filter():

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squared = list(map(lambda n: n ** 2, nums))
even = list(filter(lambda n: n % 2 == 0, nums))

docs.title: 🧮 6. Recursion
docs.text:
A function calling itself.

def factorial(n):
    if n == 0:
        return 1
    return n * factorial(n - 1)

print(factorial(5))  # 120

⚠️ Always include a base case to prevent infinite recursion.

docs.title: 🧱 7. Nested Functions
docs.text:
Functions inside other functions.

def outer():
    msg = "Hello"

    def inner():
        print(msg)

    inner()

outer()

docs.title: 🔒 8. Closures
docs.text:
Inner functions that remember the variables from their enclosing scope.

def make_multiplier(x):
    def multiply(y):
        return x * y
    return multiply

double = make_multiplier(2)
print(double(5))  # 10

docs.title: 🧬 9. Decorators
docs.text:
Functions that modify the behavior of other functions.

def logger(func):
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        print(f"Running {func.__name__}...")
        return func(*args, **kwargs)
    return wrapper

@logger
def greet():
    print("Hello!")

greet()

docs.title: 🧾 10. Type Hints
docs.text:
Add clarity and support static type checking.

def add(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    return a + b

Use mypy to check types:

mypy your_script.py

docs.title: 🧩 11. Higher-Order Functions
docs.text:
Functions that take or return other functions.

def apply(func, value):
    return func(value)

print(apply(lambda x: x * 2, 10))

docs.title: ⚙️ 12. Built-in Functions Overview
docs.text: Category Examples Math abs(), round(), sum(), min(), max() Iterables len(), sorted(), zip(), enumerate() Type Conversion int(), float(), str(), list() Logic any(), all(), bool()

docs.title: 🧠 13. Best Practices
docs.text:
Use descriptive names for clarity Keep functions small and focused Add docstrings and type hints Avoid side effects (modifying globals) Return values instead of printing when possible

© Python Cheatsheet — Functions Section

docs.title: 🧱 Python Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) Cheatsheet
docs.text: Everything you need to know about classes, objects, inheritance, encapsulation, and polymorphism in Python.

docs.title: 🧩 1. What is OOP?
docs.text: OOP (Object-Oriented Programming) organizes code into objects that bundle data (attributes) and behavior (methods).

docs.title: 🧱 2. Defining a Class
docs.text:
class Person:
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age

    def greet(self):
        print(f"Hello, my name is {self.name}.")

p1 = Person("Alice", 25)
p1.greet()

docs.title: 🧠 3. __init__ Method
docs.text:
The constructor initializes an object’s attributes when it’s created.

class Car:
    def __init__(self, brand, model):
        self.brand = brand
        self.model = model

car = Car("Tesla", "Model 3")
print(car.brand)  # Tesla

docs.title: 🧍 4. Instance Variables vs Class Variables
docs.text:
class Dog:
    species = "Canine"  # Class variable

    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name  # Instance variable

dog1 = Dog("Rex")
dog2 = Dog("Buddy")

print(dog1.species)  # Canine
print(dog1.name)     # Rex

docs.title: Instance Method
docs.text: Operates on an instance (self refers to it).

docs.title: Class Method
docs.text: Uses @classmethod and the class itself (cls).

docs.title: Static Method
docs.text:
Uses @staticmethod — doesn’t need class or instance.

class Example:
    def instance_method(self):
        return "Called instance method", self

    @classmethod
    def class_method(cls):
        return "Called class method", cls

    @staticmethod
    def static_method():
        return "Called static method"

docs.title: 🧬 6. Inheritance
docs.text:
Derive a new class (child) from another (parent).

class Animal:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def speak(self):
        print("Some sound")

class Dog(Animal):
    def speak(self):
        print("Woof!")

dog = Dog("Buddy")
dog.speak()

docs.title: super() for Parent Access
docs.text:
class Bird(Animal):
    def __init__(self, name, color):
        super().__init__(name)
        self.color = color

docs.title: 🧱 7. Encapsulation
docs.text:
Control access to data using private and protected attributes.

class Account:
    def __init__(self, balance):
        self._balance = balance      # Protected
        self.__pin = "1234"          # Private

    def get_balance(self):
        return self._balance

    def _update_balance(self, amount):
        self._balance += amount

Prefix with _ → “protected” convention (internal use). Prefix with __ → name mangling (_ClassName__var).

docs.title: 🔄 8. Polymorphism
docs.text:
Different classes share the same interface but implement behavior differently.

class Cat:
    def speak(self): return "Meow"

class Dog:
    def speak(self): return "Woof"

for animal in [Cat(), Dog()]:
    print(animal.speak())

docs.title: 🧰 9. Magic (Dunder) Methods
🧱 10. Composition (HAS-A Relationship)
docs.text:
Use other classes as attributes.

class Engine:
    def start(self):
        print("Engine starting...")

class Car:
    def __init__(self):
        self.engine = Engine()

    def start(self):
        self.engine.start()
        print("Car ready!")

docs.title: 🧩 11. Abstract Classes (Interfaces)
docs.text:
Force child classes to implement specific methods.

from abc import ABC, abstractmethod

class Shape(ABC):
    @abstractmethod
    def area(self):
        pass

class Circle(Shape):
    def __init__(self, radius):
        self.radius = radius

    def area(self):
        return 3.14 * self.radius ** 2

docs.title: 🧾 12. Property Decorator
docs.text:
Use getters and setters cleanly.

class Employee:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self._name = name

    @property
    def name(self):
        return self._name

    @name.setter
    def name(self, value):
        if not value:
            raise ValueError("Name cannot be empty")
        self._name = value

docs.title: 🧠 13. Multiple Inheritance
docs.text:
class A:
    def greet(self): print("Hello from A")

class B:
    def greet(self): print("Hello from B")

class C(A, B):
    pass

c = C()
c.greet()  # Method Resolution Order (MRO): A → B

View MRO:

print(C.mro())

docs.title: ⚙️ 14. Data Classes (Python 3.7+)
docs.text:
Automatically generate boilerplate methods.

from dataclasses import dataclass

@dataclass
class Point:
    x: int
    y: int

p = Point(3, 4)
print(p)  # Point(x=3, y=4)

docs.title: ✅ 15. Best Practices
docs.text:
✅ Use clear naming conventions ✅ Favor composition over inheritance when possible ✅ Keep classes small and focused ✅ Use properties to encapsulate data ✅ Add __repr__ for better debugging

🔗 Related Topics: - Functions

© Python Cheatsheet — OOP Section

docs.title: ⚡ Python Shortcuts & One-Liners Cheatsheet
docs.text: Boost your productivity with these Python shortcuts, tricks, and one-liners for cleaner, faster coding.

docs.title: 🧩 1. Variable Swapping
docs.text:
Swap two variables without a temporary one.

a, b = b, a

docs.title: 🧮 2. Multiple Variable Assignment
docs.text:
Assign multiple values at once.

x, y, z = 1, 2, 3

Unpack lists or tuples easily:

a, b, *rest = [10, 20, 30, 40, 50]

docs.title: 🧠 3. Inline Conditional (Ternary Operator)
docs.text:
age = 20
status = "Adult" if age >= 18 else "Minor"

docs.title: 📜 4. List Comprehensions
docs.text:
Compact way to create lists.

squares = [x**2 for x in range(10)]
evens = [x for x in range(20) if x % 2 == 0]

Nested version:

matrix = [[i * j for j in range(3)] for i in range(3)]

docs.title: 🧰 5. Dictionary & Set Comprehensions
docs.text:
squares = {x: x**2 for x in range(5)}
unique_letters = {char for char in "hello"}

docs.title: 🧾 6. Enumerate
docs.text:
Get index and value together when looping.

for index, value in enumerate(["a", "b", "c"]):
    print(index, value)

docs.title: 🪄 7. Zip
docs.text:
Combine iterables.

names = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]
scores = [85, 90, 95]

for name, score in zip(names, scores):
    print(name, score)

Unzip with *:

zipped = list(zip(names, scores))
names, scores = zip(*zipped)

docs.title: ⚙️ 8. Inline Functions (Lambdas)
docs.text:
Short anonymous functions.

square = lambda x: x ** 2
add = lambda a, b: a + b

Use with map() or filter():

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squared = list(map(lambda x: x**2, nums))
even = list(filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0, nums))

docs.title: 🧮 9. Join & Split Strings
docs.text:
words = ["Python", "is", "awesome"]
sentence = " ".join(words)

chars = "A-B-C".split("-")

docs.title: 🧱 10. Reversing Collections
docs.text:
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]
print(nums[::-1])
print(list(reversed(nums)))

Reverse a string:

text = "Python"
print(text[::-1])  # nohtyP

docs.title: 🧠 11. Get Unique Items (Remove Duplicates)
docs.text:
unique = list(set([1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 4]))

Preserve order (Python 3.7+):

unique_ordered = list(dict.fromkeys([1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 4]))

docs.title: 🧾 12. Counting Elements Quickly
docs.text:
from collections import Counter

nums = [1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3]
count = Counter(nums)
print(count.most_common(1))  # [(3, 3)]

docs.title: 🔄 13. Flatten a List of Lists
docs.text:
matrix = [[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6]]
flat = [num for row in matrix for num in row]

docs.title: 🧰 14. Sort with Custom Keys
docs.text:
words = ["apple", "banana", "pear"]
sorted_words = sorted(words, key=len)

Reverse sort:

nums = [3, 1, 4, 2]
sorted_desc = sorted(nums, reverse=True)

docs.title: 🧩 15. Inline File Reading
docs.text: lines = [line.strip() for line in open("file.txt")]

docs.title: ⚙️ 16. Using any() and all()
docs.text:
nums = [1, 2, 3, 0]
print(any(nums))  # True if any item is truthy
print(all(nums))  # True if all items are truthy

docs.title: 🧮 17. Chained Comparisons
docs.text:
x = 5
if 1 < x < 10:
    print("In range!")

docs.title: 🔢 18. FizzBuzz One-Liner
docs.text: [("Fizz"*(i%3==0) + "Buzz"*(i%5==0) or i) for i in range(1, 21)]

docs.title: 🧩 19. Merging Dictionaries
docs.text:
a = {"x": 1, "y": 2}
b = {"y": 3, "z": 4}
merged = {**a, **b}

docs.title: 🪄 20. Debugging Shortcut
docs.text:
Quickly inspect variables.

x = 42
print(f"{x=}")  # Prints: x=42

docs.title: 🧮 21. List Repetition
docs.text: zeros = [0] * 5  # [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]

docs.title: 🧰 22. Compact Conditional Loops
docs.text: nums = [x for x in range(10) if x % 2 == 0]

docs.title: 🧠 23. Dictionary to List Conversion
docs.text:
data = {"a": 1, "b": 2, "c": 3}
items = list(data.items())
keys = list(data.keys())
values = list(data.values())

docs.title: 🪄 24. Find Index Safely
docs.text:
try:
    index = my_list.index("target")
except ValueError:
    index = -1

docs.title: ⚡ 25. Simple Timer
docs.text:
import time
start = time.time()

# your code here

print(f"Execution time: {time.time() - start:.2f}s")

✅ Bonus Tip: Use python -i script.py to open an interactive shell after running your script — perfect for debugging!
